title: Overview
text:
All code for this course will be made available in a public repository (repo) on Github: https://github.com/AlkemaLab/BayesCode.
We will use the open-source software R for analyses and computations, through its user-friendly interface R-studio (https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio/). For model fitting, R packages and extensions are used such that all analyses take place in R. Analysis scripts will be provided for example analyses and discussed in recordings.
The remainder of this page contains a workflow for non-Github users, and some resources if you’d like to brush up on your R skills.

title: Welcome to Applied Bayesian modeling!
text:
Welcome to the course website for Applied Bayesian Modeling! This course is taught by Leontine Alkema at UMass Amherst (BIOSTATS 730).
Please check out the general information and modules on this website. Additional course information for enrolled students is on the Canvas course page. More content for others will/may be added here “soon”.
Lecture material (slides, notes, videos) are licensed under CC-BY-NC 4.0. Code is licensed under BSD-3. HWs and exams and their solutions may not be shared without Leontine Alkema’s approval.
Thanks to all who helped improve the content of this course! Special thanks for questions, input, and discussions that have shaped and improved the content to past and current students in the Alkema lab and students who participated in prior offerings of Bayesian modeling at UMass Amherst and Berkeley.
Contact: Leontine Alkema (lalkema@umass.edu)

title: Modules
text:
Why would we want to introduce Bayesian statistical models to produce estimates and forecasts for Countdown coverage indicators?

Link to slides
Link to recording




The training is divided into 5 modules:

Introduction to Bayesian inference and Bayesian modeling in global health
How to exchange information between populations: Hierarchical models (also called multilevel models)
How to best use data to inform estimates: Data models for survey and routine surveillance data  
What assumptions to make about indicators and how they change with time: Time series process models, focused on transition models 
Putting it all together: Using Bayesian hierarchical transition models for model fitting, how to go about it, what to check?

In each module, topics include conceptual understanding as well as hands-on analysis and modeling exercises. The schedule can be found here.
